channel.title: Microsoft does open source again? Barrelfish OS
channel.description:
You've likely heard of Microsoft's next-gen operating system projects Midori and Singularity, but earlier this month researchers released a prototype for another OS, code-named Barrelfish. Barrelfish is an OS written specifically for multicore environments. It hopes to improve the performance of boxes with such chips by creating a network bus, if you will, between cores. Today such systems tend to share resources like memory. As demand increases, performance of the box decreases as shared resources don't scale well. Barrelfish instead passes messages between cores on its bus, and reportedly uses a database-like approach to keep track of the hardware available. The project hasn't exactly been a secret. Researchers have been trotting the globe lecturing on it for about a year. But they were shy about releasing code. On Sept. 15, that changed with the release of the first snapshot of the OS. Microsoft Research, Cambridge, created Barrelfish in conjunction with ETH Zurich, a technology university. Rumors have swirled that the OS is going to be completely free and open source, as it includes some BSD third-party libraries, which are "covered by various BSD-like open source licenses," the Barrelfish team says. But we'll have to wait and see on that. This early take-a-peek code is being released under a copyright held by ETH Zurich and Microsoft. According to a blog post by a blogger,Advogato,on Advogato, who attended a lecture by one of those globe-trotting researchers: [quote]"... instead of fully isolating program from device via driver, Barrelfish has a kind of database where lots of low level information about the hardware can be found. The kernel is single threaded and non preemptive. Scheduling is coupled with the message passing, an arrival of the message simply activates the waiting thread. It also uses a little bit of the microkernel concepts, running drivers in protected space, like L4 and in general pushing a lot into application domains."[/quote] Here is a diagram of Barrelfish from its creators. Click on it for the full research paper. [url=http://www.barrelfish.org/barrelfish_sosp09.pdf][img]http://www.networkworld.com/Micronet%20images/barrelfish.jpg[/img][/url]
Source: http://www.networkworld.com/community/node/45615?source=NWWNLE_nlt_daily_pm_2009-09-25 It says that it may be open source, so who knows. They now have three "next-generation" Operating Systems being developed. We can only assume they are going to be replacing Windows for whatever reasons. I am interested into seeing where this one is going to go, though. It seems like a pretty good idea to me.

item.title: Microsoft does open source again? Barrelfish OS
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Who the hell would rewrite an entire operating system complete with tools from scratch when there are so many open source tools available to use? (GNU, BSD, etc) Stupid.

Microsoft wouldn’t build an entire OS just to research some new concepts
[/quote]

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singularity_(operating_system)[/quote]

I stand corrected. But I also stand next to Barrelfish becoming a full-fledged operating system.

item.title: Microsoft does open source again? Barrelfish OS
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Taharok:

Microsoft wouldn’t build an entire OS just to research some new concepts

en.wikipedia.org

Singularity (operating system)

Singularity is an experimental operating system (OS) which was built by Microsoft Research between 2003 and 2010. It was designed as a high dependability OS in which the kernel, device drivers, and application software were all written in managed code. Internal security uses type safety instead of hardware memory protection. The lowest-level x86 interrupt dispatch code is written in assembly language and C. Once this code has done its job, it invokes the kernel, which runtime system and garbage...

item.title: Microsoft does open source again? Barrelfish OS
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:20, topic:304803”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=401082.msg2979919#msg2979919 date=1254547093]

That would be called “research”, they dump millions into it every year

Their research would just be thrown back into Windows again. Microsoft wouldn’t build an entire OS just to research some new concepts, nor would they team up with outside developers for the same reasons.
[/quote]

This doesn’t look like it is an entire OS, rather just a kernel, right?[/quote]

They’re calling it an OS, so I’m assuming it’s going to be developed into an entire OS.

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft does open source again? Barrelfish OS
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

Don’t you think the point of this OS was to educate those who made it? It’s partially made by students of an Austrian university.

The point of the OS is to allow more eased control between using multiple cores and having those cores communicate with one another. Microsoft isn’t going to make an operating system that has no point to it. That’d be a huge waste of resources for them.

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft does open source again? Barrelfish OS
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:13, topic:304803”][quote author=runescape3dude link=topic=401082.msg2977454#msg2977454 date=1254374118]

From that article it doesn’t look like open source to me, more like “here is the source, you can only look at it and even then you are not legally allowed to remember any of it”. For a program to be open source, it needs to have an accompanying open source license.

http://barrelfish.org you can download it here and compile it.
[/quote]

Barrelfish is released under the 3-clause BSD-style Open Source licence.

I guess that’s that then. This really is an open source OS. :|[/quote]

Oh, alright then, not too shabby. If this is of any worth perhaps we will see a kFreeBSD style kBarrelfish ‘port’ for it.

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft does open source again? Barrelfish OS
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

sanga282:

i doubt they will tbh windows has been a mainstay for ages, and because people arent all computer minded yet they would get confused by something as simple as a name change

Microsoft doesn’t care about that. Window has been, and is a business-directed Operating System. If they really are planning on branching out to three new OS’s, that’s a lot better solution than cramming everything into 1. They could create an efficient server-class Operating System, a feature-some personal Operating System, and a business-class OS. I don’t think this is exactly what they’re doing, but it would be ideal in my book.

Read full topic
